defaultClubs.name: Ballroom Dance Club
defaultClubs.description: Ballroom is a fun physical activity that provides stress relief and allows you to build relationships and friends with other members. You can improve your posture, build confidence and add this to your resume. You might be surprised that most of the top Adult Amateur ballroom dancers in the US are Computer Science or Engineering majors/graduates and you might even have one of them interview you for your next job!
defaultClubs.goals: The main goals of the organization is to learn the basics of various ballroom dances like Waltz, Cha-cha, Tango, Rumba, Samba, Swing, etc in a fun and engaging environment. We have opportunities to perform for the ballroom dance community in Hawaii. We also participate in the ballroom dance competitions that are held twice a year in the State of Hawaii.

defaultClubs.name: Robotic Space Exploration
defaultClubs.description: Team RoSE is concerned with the fabrication, dynamics, controls, systems engineering, and machine learning for space applications. The main driving force for the team is the University Rover Challenge (URC). URC, which is an international competition to design the next generation of rovers for robotic exploration. Rovers from other teams and previous years can be seen in the links section. These models are from years of iterations, modifications, and redesigns. There are four sections of emphases to the URC: science, retrieval, service, and autonomy.
defaultClubs.goals: Team RoSE has the goal to create a professional and safe atmosphere for students to collaborate on an engineering project that aims to design and fabricate a rover for the University Rover Challenge.

defaultClubs.name: AlohaThon Dance Marathon
defaultClubs.description: AlohaThon is a nonprofit and part of the Children’s Miracle Network Organization. Children’s Miracle Network supports different Dance Marathons around U.S college campuses in order to raise money for their local Children’s Miracle Network Hospitals. Our local CMN hospital which serves the state of Hawaiʻi and the Pacific region, is Kapiʻolani Medical Center for Women and Children. All 100% of our funds raised are donated directed to Kapiʻolani and last year we raised over $20,000. In the previous years, money raised went towards building their new NICU. This year we are looking to expand our event in order to raise the most money that we can for Kapiʻolani.
defaultClubs.goals: Our organization is dedicated to promoting professional growth, networking, and community engagement for members interested in Professional, Recreational, ICS. We strive to create an inclusive and supportive environment for all AlohaThon Dance Marathon members.

defaultClubs.name: Anthropology Graduate Student Association
defaultClubs.description:
AGSA, a volunteer organization comprised of graduate students in the Department of Anthropology, has 2 primary goals:

1. To support graduate student research, projects, and outreach activities. 
2. To assist in the facilitation of faculty-graduate student communication and student retention, and act as an interface between department administration and the graduate student body. 
3. To support the overall graduate student experience through social and group activities.

AGSA also interfaces with the Graduate Student Organization (GSO), which represents the interests of graduate students across campus. Additionally, AGSA organizes a number of events including occasional professional development workshop series, an annual graduate student research symposium, and occasional community service projects.
defaultClubs.goals: At Anthropology Graduate Student Association, we believe in fostering the growth and success of our members through opportunities for professional development, networking, and community involvement in the areas of Engineering, ICS, Leisure.

defaultClubs.name: Anthropology Undergraduate Student Association
defaultClubs.description:
(1) The creation of an accessible means for all students interested in anthropology to gain familiarity with the diverse areas of study within the discipline, and to utilize the resources that are available to them through the University of Hawai'i at Manoa, the College of Social Sciences, & the Department of Anthropology.
(2) A forum for students to network through discussion of current events, topics, and debates relevant to anthropology and related disciplines. 
(3) Provide interested students with guidance, support and practical experience to adequately prepare them for a career and/or graduate/post-baccalaureate studies in anthropology.
(4) Offer opportunities for students to practice their kuleana (responsibility) within the community and learn invaluable skills through a variety of volunteer and learning opportunities.
defaultClubs.goals: Anthropology Undergraduate Student Association is dedicated to promoting professional excellence, personal growth, and community involvement for our members in the areas of Academic, ICS, Leisure. defaultClubs.name: Asian-Pacific Law & Policy Journal
defaultClubs.description: The Asian-Pacific Law and Policy Journal (APLPJ) is a web-based, American legal journal covering issues in Asia and the Pacific Rim. Our objectives are to disseminate legal research by law professors, legal practitioners, social scientists, economists, and students; to increase awareness of legal issues impacting the region and to provide a forum to discuss legal topics that fall within the Journal’s geographic scope. APLPJ publishes articles, translations, book reviews, essays, case notes, and comments on current topics in comparative and transnational law focused on one or more countries or geographic entities in the Asia-Pacific region.

defaultClubs.name: Association for Women in Math - University of Hawai'i at Mānoa chapter
defaultClubs.description: Since its founding in 1971 by a small but passionate group of women mathematicians, the Association for Women in Mathematics (AWM) has grown into a leading society for women in the mathematical sciences, and is one of the societies comprising the Conference Board of the Mathematical Sciences. AWM’s programs not only support those who participate in them directly, but also help influence the mathematics culture more generally, so that young women entering the field today encounter an environment that is more nurturing than that of the 1970’s and 1980’s. Throughout its 50 year History, the AWM has played a critical role in increasing the presence and visibility of women in the mathematical sciences.

defaultClubs.name: Botanical Society of America Hawai'i Chapter at University of Hawai'i at Manoa
defaultClubs.description: The Botanical Society of America ("BSA") Hawai'i Chapter ("Chapter") shall be operated for scientific and educational purposes. Its mission is to promote botany, the field of basic science dealing with the study and inquiry into the form, function, development, diversity, reproduction, evolution, and uses of plants and their interactions within the biosphere. defaultClubs.name: E1R1
defaultClubs.description:
"The Collective is enacted to serve the underserved community in Honolulu, HI and at University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa through Hip Hop dance. The Collective aims to provide “pathways into higher education” workshops, free dance classes, and performances by the Collective both at the UH Mānoa (outside and within the dance department) and within the community at large, such as elementary schools, middle schools, high schools, community colleges, and various promotional and community events. The Collective acknowledges the sanctity of Black life and aims to rectify academic racism with the promotion of anti-oppression, anti-racism, and liberation as guiding principles within all activities and events. To recognize the sanctity of Black life and POC as creators and participants of Hip Hop culture, the Collective will utilize intersectional and interdisciplinary approaches to social justice and community service through Hip Hop dance. The Collective will seek to establish a relationship between UH Mānoa and the Honolulu community which denounces structural inequality, colonialism, settler colonialism, racism, hetereopatriarchy (in all its forms including anti-Black misogyny), orientalism, white supremacist ideology, and homophobia. The Collective aims to enact coalitional collaboration across differences as the Collective is of mixed backgrounds, with acknowledgement of the land on which we practice as stolen from Native Hawaiian, Kanaka Maoli, and Pacific Islander peoples.


The mission of E1R1 Collective is to serve the underserved community in Honolulu, Hi through hip-hop dance. We do this by providing free workshops, dance classes, and performances to the community. "
defaultClubs.goals: At E1R1, we believe in fostering the growth and success of our members through opportunities for professional development, networking, and community involvement in the areas of Service, ICS, Academic.

defaultClubs.name: Generation Action
defaultClubs.description: Generation Action at the University of Hawaii at Manoa is an affiliate of Planned Parenthood Action Fund. It is a movement of diverse college professionals seeking to engage peers and community members in fighting for reproductive health and freedom, racial equity, inclusivity, and other such important issues. Generation Action encourages others to mobilize into political action to defend and fight for progressive policy at city, state, and national levels. Generation Action serves as a coalition partner to allies at the state, national, and international reproductive rights efforts. Generation Action believes in the fundamental right of every individual to manage his or her reproductive health and to have full access to comprehensive reproductive and complementary health care services in settings that preserve and protect the essential privacy and rights of each individual. Generation Action advocates for public policies that guarantee these rights and insure access to such services. Generation Action also supports access to medically accurate educational programs that enhance one’s understanding of human sexuality. Generation Action also acknowledges and supports the dynamic perspective and intersectional framework that young people are using to connect reproductive health to other issues such as civil rights, immigration, the environment,gender identity policies and other related social justice issues.

defaultClubs.name: Mortar Board National Honor Society Hui Poʻokela Chapter at the University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa
defaultClubs.description: Mortar Board Senior National Honor Society has long been recognized in the O'ahu community for its continued partnership with diverse service projects with other student clubs and non-profit organizations all over the island. This is a national collegiate honor society for students in their senior year. Each chapter is typically composed of only a handful of carefully selected applicants for the year - the Hui Po'okela Chapter usually does not exceed 25 members at a time. Potential members are chosen based on how they measure in accord with Mortar Board's key values: scholarship, leadership, and service. Those who excel in said values are then carefully examined through a series of interviews hosted by the chapter's current members. It is a great opportunity to give back to the community and form close friendships with fellow Mortar Board members. This honor society is more than just prestige, but rather, an opportunity for every undergraduate senior to make a local impact in their campus and community before they graduate. Once initiated in Mortar Board, every member will engage in various community service and fundraising activities. We not only help support each other and the Oʻahu community through various events but above all, we are making a global impact by building and growing the best leaders of tomorrow.
defaultClubs.goals: The main goals of Mortar Board National Honor Society Hui Poʻokela Chapter at the University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa are to promote professional and technical development, facilitate networking, and enrich the lives of Mortar Board National Honor Society Hui Poʻokela Chapter at the University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa members in the areas of Leisure, Recreational, Social.

The club has five main goals: 1) Broad acceptance of all including but not limited to individuals within the student body of the University of Hawai‘i at Mānoa (UHM) and local communities, emphasizing the understanding of peace within the individual, group, and society, 2) Fostering informal conversations on conflicts we face and emphasize coping strategies and supports, inclusion, and empathy, 3) Increasing informal and formal oral communication skills and group problem solving, 4) Teaching current and future students of UHM about the efforts of the Matsunaga Institute for Peace (Matsunaga Institute), and 5) Connecting with the community and empower UHM voices so we can help create and empower diverse and distinct identities.

defaultClubs.name: Student Nurses' Association at UH Manoa
defaultClubs.description:
A. To assume responsibility for contributing to nursing education in order to provide for the
highest quality of health care.

B. To provide programs representative of fundamental interests and concerns to nursing
students.

C. To aid in the development of the whole person, including his/her professional role,
his/her responsibility for health care of people in all walks of life.
1. SNA members will work to create a positive, professional atmosphere, which will focus on mentorship, leadership, and collaboration.
2. To promote open communication and collaboration throughout the student body,
faculty, and administration of the nursing program.
3. To select students as representatives to participate on school committees in order
to share responsibility and accountability for governance within the nursing
program.
4. SNA officers and class representatives will act as advocates for nursing students
by effectively articulating the collective concerns of the student body through the
established channels of communication at the Department of Nursing.
5. To foster and develop mentoring relationships among students by assisting new students in the school orientation program and offering ongoing assistance on a
formal and/or informal basis.
6. To promote participation in all SNA/class activities and opportunities to develop
leadership skills through various volunteer, social, educational, and fundraising
activities.
7. To represent the students of the Department of Nursing (DON) in the pursuit of
excellence in educational training toward competent, professional care and
practice.
8. To facilitate student knowledge of and participation in professional nursing
organizations.
9. To assist in increased public understanding of the role of the student and
professional nurse beyond the clinical setting.
10. To seek and provide service opportunities for students that meet the health care
needs and wellbeing of community members regardless of race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, socioeconomic status, age, physical abilities, political beliefs, religious beliefs, nationality, or other ideologies.
defaultClubs.goals: Student Nurses' Association at UH Manoa aims to support the development and growth of our members through opportunities for professional advancement, networking, and personal enrichment in the areas of ICS, Engineering, Service.

defaultClubs.name: Students for Life at the University of Hawaii, Manoa
defaultClubs.description:
Students for Life at University of Hawaii Manoa
(SFL- UHM) was founded in November, 2022, to form a community of pro-life students on campus. Members of SFL-UHM work to protect life from conception to natural death, particularly those lives threatened by abortion, infanticide, embryonic stem cell research, and euthanasia. In furtherance of these goals, members seek to promote respect for life at UHM and on a local, state and national level, to educate people on life issues, to help those in need see that life is a promising choice and to work with others who share common goals.
defaultClubs.goals: Students for Life at the University of Hawaii, Manoa aims to support the development and growth of our members through opportunities for professional advancement, networking, and personal enrichment in the areas of ICS, Engineering, Academic.

IMUA Labs is established to foster inclusive ecosocial innovation, advance transdisciplinary knowledge production, and promote systemic literacy for the benefit of all communities that call The Hawaiian Islands their home. ➤To serve the needs of students of the Ilokano language and literature program and others interested in the Ilokano the Ilokano language and Philippine culture.

Not only designed for students to network, TIMSA is built upon the foundation of community and giving back.
